author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Amy Adams, Marielle Heller and How ‘Nightbitch’ Speaks to Women
description: They set out to subvert expectations for depictions of motherhood. “There’s conscientious discomfort,” Heller says. Reactions have been polarized.
content: Within the first 30 minutes of the magical realist dramedy “Nightbitch,” Amy Adams, starring as a newish parent teeming with fury and resentment, discovers that the oozing pustule that appeared on her back contains what appears to be a tail, the clearest sign yet that she is transforming into a dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Matei Barbulescu
title: Romanian Court Annuls Presidential Election Results and Orders a New Vote
description: The decision came days after the government asserted that there had been “cyberattacks” meant to undermine the vote and security council documents indicated possible Russian meddling.
content: Europe’s efforts to contain a resurgence of nationalism and Russian interference entered dangerous new territory on Friday when Romania canceled a high-stakes presidential election, just two days before a runoff vote that an ultranationalist candidate had been well positioned to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Mary’ Review: An Epic Biopic for the Mother of God
description: No genre gesture goes untapped in this Netflix film, a coming-of-age saga about the Virgin Mary featuring Anthony Hopkins as King Herod.
content: Horses gallop across a desert. Christianity’s most famous couple meet cute at a river. Swords clatter. A villain emerges from flames. Insect buzz accompanies the come-ons of a devil. (OK, the Devil.) No genre gesture goes untapped in the deliberately hagiographic “Mary,” a coming-of-age saga about the mother of Jesus. Directed by D.J. Caruso and written by Timothy Michael Hayes, the film aims to draw multitudes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Rocket Mortgage Sues HUD Over Its Inclusion in Appraisal Lawsuit
description: The nation’s largest lender says the government tied its hands with regulations that prevented it from exerting control over appraisal values.
content: Rocket Mortgage, the nation’s largest lender, has sued the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, saying its reputation was sullied by a Justice Department lawsuit over appraisal bias, and that it should not have been included in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Could Facial Recognition Help Find Man Sought in C.E.O.’s Killing?
description: Experts disagreed on whether running surveillance camera images released by the police through a facial recognition system would produce a reliable lead.
content: A man whom the police are seeking in connection to the brazen killing of Brian Thompson, the UnitedHealthcare chief executive, has passed by numerous surveillance cameras while in Manhattan. Could artificial intelligence-powered facial recognition put a name to the man whose identity has so far eluded the authorities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Iran Makes ‘Dramatic’ Leap to Produce Near-Bomb-Grade Fuel, but to What End?
description: The United Nations chief inspector says production has quadrupled. But it is not clear whether Iran is trying to touch off a crisis or gather bargaining chips for negotiations with the United States.
content: The United Nations’ chief nuclear inspector said on Friday that Iran was quadrupling its production of near-bomb-grade material, a move likely to intensify the challenge it will pose to the incoming Trump administration — but one that might also open the way to a new negotiation with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Why Wouldn’t ChatGPT Say This Dead Professor’s Name?
description: A bizarre saga in which users noticed the chatbot refused to say “David Mayer” raised questions about privacy and A.I., with few clear answers.
content: Across the final years of his life, David Mayer, a theater professor living in Manchester, England, faced the cascading consequences of an unfortunate coincidence: A dead Chechen rebel on a terror watch list had once used Mr. Mayer’s name as an alias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Office Holiday Party Is Back. But What to Wear?
description: Tips from The Times’ fashion director on how to navigate the sartorial anxieties of the season.
content: Ah, the joys of Christmas: sleigh bells, fir trees, Santas, the office holiday party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Air Force Not Ready to Stop Buying Human-Piloted Jets
description: Elon Musk has mocked the Air Force for continuing to purchase expensive traditional fighter jets instead of drones. But military officials say human pilots are still needed.
content: The Air Force is at least decades away from being ready to stop buying and flying human-piloted fighter jets like the F-35, but it also does not want to rush into building a next generation of these high-priced fighting machines until it has a better idea of just what it needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Jonathan Blezard
title: How Notre-Dame Was Reborn
description: It took about 250 companies, 2,000 workers, about $900 million, a tight deadline and a lot of national pride.
content: The embers of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris were still hot when President Emmanuel Macron vowed that France would rebuild it to be “more beautiful than ever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a sneaky serial killer, a boy’s vengeance quest and a holiday house of horrors.
content: M. Night Shyamalan’s latest psychological thriller is so preposterous it makes “The Front Room,” my pick for the dumbest horror movie of 2024, look like “The Shining.” But unlike “The Front Room,” “Trap” takes itself very unseriously — God, I hope it does — and watching it was the most fun I had at a horror movie this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: For Those in Need of a Job, Landing One Might Still Be a Challenge
description: Layoffs remain relatively low, but people who lose their jobs could be struggling to find new ones.
content: The unemployment rate, which ticked up slightly to 4.2 percent in November, remains low by historical standards. But under the surface, there are signs that it can be difficult to land a job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Jenny Gross
title: Inside ‘Rail Force One’: The Trains That Take World Leaders to Ukraine
description: With airspace closed and missiles flying, visiting Kyiv typically means 10 hours on bumpy tracks — even for presidents, prime ministers and business magnates. It’s plenty of time to reflect.
content: In the nearly three years since Russia invaded Ukraine, Ursula von der Leyen, the European Union’s top official, has grown accustomed to the 10-hour overnight train ride to Kyiv. She passes the time preparing for meetings and reading books about Ukraine, when she is not trying to catch some sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Houseplants Can Make You Healthier
description: You don’t need a green thumb to reap the benefits.
content: I was on the phone with a friend the other day, and because I can’t sit still, I started to dust the leaves on my sprawling bird of paradise plant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatriz Milhazes
title: An Art Movement’s Lasting Impression
description: Lessons from the past continue to influence and inspire today’s globalized art world.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Obsessed With Light’ and the Dancer We All Should Know
description: The film argues that Loie Fuller was an inventive artist responsible for things we take for granted. If only the movie were as creative as its star.
content: The master cinematographer Vittorio Storaro has described cinema as “writing with light,” a description I’ve always found — dare I say it? — illuminating. I love that when you watch a movie with a projector, whether you’re in a cinema or someone’s living room, you can accidentally interrupt the picture with your body if it blocks the light. I love that the image can change based on the quality of the light shining through the film or the screen. There’s something wonderfully physical and ephemeral about the experience that even the shift to digital movies hasn’t altogether eradicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eryn Davis, Andy Newman and Maria Cramer
title: Police in Central Park Find Backpack Like the One the Gunman Carried
description: Crime scene technicians came to a wooded area where officers were searching for the gunman’s bag and weapon.
content: New York police officers on Friday found a backpack in Central Park that they believe was carried by the man who fatally shot the UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson, according to two law enforcement officials familiar with the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: A $400 Billion Clean Energy Program Is Racing to Get Money Out the Door
description: Some fear Donald Trump could freeze the Energy Department’s loan office, which supports electric vehicles, geothermal, nuclear and other novel technologies.
content: At the heart of the Biden administration’s efforts to advance clean energy is a $400 billion lending program that has backed dozens of projects across the nation, including battery factories in Ohio and Tennessee, the revival of a shuttered nuclear reactor in Michigan and a novel rooftop solar expansion in Puerto Rico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: At the Top of Her Bucket List: Saying ‘I Do’
description: When Moira Legault, who has brain cancer, was given about a year to live, she knew she wanted to spend the rest of her life with Tyler Ferron.
content: Moira Collette-Jean Legault had just awakened from a brain operation when she received some devastating news. She would most likely have about a year to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmitry Muratov
title: We Cannot Forget the World’s Political Prisoners
description: No mission is more important than preserving the lives of those who have been jailed for their principles.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Israeli Attacks Around Gaza Hospital Kill or Wound Scores, Doctors Say
description: Airstrikes, gunfire, panic and orders to evacuate in the dark of night combined to cause heavy casualties in the area of Kamal Adwan, one of the last hospitals still operating in northern Gaza.
content: Israeli airstrikes and intense gunfire on the ground around one of the last working hospitals in northern Gaza killed or wounded scores of people early Friday, the hospital’s director said, as Israeli forces ordered the building evacuated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
title: Trump’s Allies Go Global: ‘Make Argentina Great Again’
description: At its international conferences, CPAC is giving a stage to right-wing politicians and hunting for ideas for use back home.
content: From a distance, Alejo de Gennaro would have fit in at any Trump rally. He wore a MAGA hat and a wide smile as he listened to a parade of speakers slam socialists and decry wokeness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Trump Picks Former Senator and Election Denier to Be Ambassador to China
description: David Perdue would serve in the role at a time when the U.S.-China relationship is considered to be the most consequential in the world.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Thursday that he would nominate David Perdue, a businessman and former senator from Georgia, to be his ambassador to China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Turning Point
description: We wish you a merry Robyn Weintraub Day.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Close Friendship That Developed Into a ‘Soulful Connection’
description: Although Samantha Greenstone had many gay friends, her relationship with Jacob Hoff, whom she met nine years ago, was different.
content: Jacob Martin Hoff said, “It was love at first cackle,” when he met Samantha Wynn Greenstone in the lobby of the theater at the Welk, a resort in Escondido, Calif., on Nov. 30, 2015. The two, both actors, were attending a callback for “Fiddler on the Roof.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Shuntaro Tanikawa, Poet and Translator of ‘Peanuts,’ Dies at 92
description: A perennial front-runner for the Nobel Prize in Literature, he was a revered figure in Japan, not just in literary circles but also among casual readers.
content: Shuntaro Tanikawa, Japan’s most popular poet for more than half a century, whose stark and whimsical poems, blending humor with melancholy, made him a kind of Everyman philosopher ideally suited to translating the “Peanuts” comic strip and Mother Goose rhymes into Japanese, died on Nov. 13 in Tokyo. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Review: William Kentridge’s Collaged Fever Dream of Shostakovich
description: Kentridge’s film played over Shostakovich’s 10th symphony at a New York Philharmonic concert led by Keri-Lynn Wilson.
content: At the USSR Museum, a two hour’s drive from Moscow, visitors can peruse copies of Pravda and Izvestia in a 1960s-style apartment replete with tarpaulin boots and aluminum spoons, part of “a hidden world,” its website says, “of emotional memories and warm nostalgia.” On Thursday, the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Keri-Lynn Wilson turned David Geffen Hall into a different kind of museum of Soviet history. This one was a film designed by the South African artist William Kentridge, with Constructivist puppets cavorting in dollhouse galleries projected over the orchestra’s reading of Shostakovich’s Symphony No. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Arsonists Set Fire to Melbourne Synagogue
description: Witnesses saw two people pouring accelerant in the synagogue early Friday, the police said. Australia’s prime minister condemned the attack as antisemitism.
content: The police in Australia are looking for several people who they believe intentionally set fire to a synagogue in a suburb of Melbourne on Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Woman Who Fell Into Sinkhole Is Found Dead
description: After searching since Tuesday, the authorities in Unity Township, Pa., on Friday found the body of Elizabeth Pollard, 64, who disappeared while searching for her cat.
content: A 64-year-old woman who fell into a sinkhole in a former coal mining community in western Pennsylvania on Monday evening, apparently while looking for her missing cat, has been found dead, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Melania Trump Credits Barron Trump With Helping His Father Win
description: “He was very vocal” in advising his father on appearing with media personalities popular with young people, Melania Trump said on the morning show “Fox & Friends.”
content: In her first interview since her husband won the presidential election, the former and future first lady Melania Trump said on Friday that their son, Barron, had played an important role in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory, advising him to appear with media personalities popular with younger voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Federal Judge Upholds Racial Preferences in Naval Academy Admissions
description: A group that successfully challenged affirmative action at the Supreme Court had also sued the military academies. But, the judge said, “the U.S. Naval Academy is distinct from a civilian university.”
content: A federal judge on Friday denied an effort to stop the U.S. Naval Academy from considering race and ethnicity in admissions, finding that the academy has a distinct interest in using affirmative action to achieve diversity in its student body, and that doing so is a matter of national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Political Turmoil Adds to South Korea’s Economic Woes
description: Even before a short-lived declaration of martial law thrust the country into crisis, the economy faced grim prospects.
content: The fallout from the short-lived declaration of martial law by President Yoon Suk Yeol has heaped another worry onto South Korea’s economy, which was already teetering from slowing growth and fears about damage to exports from a shift in U.S. trade policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gennaro Tomma
title: When They Hear Plants Crying, Moths Make a Decision
description: A new study suggests that the insects rely on the sounds made by distressed vegetation to guide important reproductive choices.
content: You may not want to sit next to a crying baby on an airplane. Apparently, moths feel the same way about plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Two Officiants Walk Into a Wine Bar
description: Kaitlyn Barclay and Ingrid Parl have each performed wedding ceremonies for three couples. They recently had their own.
content: Kaitlyn Elizabeth Barclay and Ingrid Sheila Parl are both known in their social circles to be that friend you can call about relationship drama or a first date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Best Podcasts of 2024
description: This year’s standouts feature staggering investigations, sparkling conversations and a retooling of the celebrity interview.
content: The 10 best podcasts of the year, listed here in alphabetical order, represent a broad sampling of the medium’s many formats — chat shows, documentaries, storytelling, interviews, true crime. Whether cracking open one of the darkest cases in American military history, giving voice to members of a vast diaspora, or interrogating the craft of audio journalism itself, these shows make a strong argument for the vitality of the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Falling in Love With Nora Ephron
description: Ilana Kaplan’s new coffee table book pays tribute to the godmother of the modern rom-com.
content: “I’ll have what she’s having.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: How an Orchestra Plays Along With a Live Video Game
description: A controller will direct a conductor’s baton during live performances of Journey at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
content: For each music cue in the dreamlike, solemn odyssey of the video game Journey, the engine tracking the player’s behavior pulls from a library of compositions, scoring a dynamic path through the game’s vast desert landscapes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Transgender Case, and the Role of Activists
description: Readers discuss the Supreme Court case and the threats trans people face. Also: Recess appointments; Social Security; pardons; brain injuries and crime.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ron O’Brien, 86, Dies; Coached Louganis and Other Diving Champs
description: His divers won more than 300 medals at major domestic and international competitions, including a dozen at the Olympics.
content: Ron O’Brien, perhaps the most successful diving coach in United States history, who guided Greg Louganis to Olympic gold in two events at the Summer Games in 1984 and again in 1988, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and David Montgomery
title: Texas House Speaker, Targeted by the Right, Drops Bid for Another Term
description: In the long-running war inside the Texas G.O.P., Dade Phelan survived a primary against a Trump-backed novice. But his increasingly conservative caucus turned against him.
content: The speaker of the Texas House, Dade Phelan, on Friday dropped his bid to continue his leadership, bowing to pressure from hard-right members of the Republican caucus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Insurer Reverses Policy That Would Have Limited Anesthesia Periods
description: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield officials had planned to roll out the changes nationwide but said they were misunderstood.
content: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield, a major health insurer, on Thursday rolled back a policy change that would have capped payments for anesthesia for patients, and would have denied claims altogether if any given procedure exceeded a time limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: From the Beginning, Speaking the Same Language
description: Laura Guerrero and Temoc Gonzalez, both from Guadalajara, Mexico, met through Instagram and felt an instant connection. “We spoke in Spanglish and just clicked,” Mr. Gonzalez said.
content: Temoc Herrera Gonzalez was instantly smitten when he saw a tagged picture of Laura Guerrero on the Instagram account of the Spanish restaurant Loquita Santa Barbara in August 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams and Harry Mitchell
title: A London Apartment Where Family Life and Treasured Artworks Coexist
description: Mathieu Paris and Razid Kalfane have transformed a neglected flat in Marylebone into a home — and a showcase for their gallery-quality collection.
content: PASS THROUGH THE front door of Mathieu Paris’s three-bedroom apartment, on the top floor of a brick four-story Victorian building in London’s Marylebone neighborhood, and you might think that you’ve inadvertently wandered into an art gallery rather than the home of new parents and their toddler daughter. But given that Paris, 41, is the global sales director of White Cube, the international gallery with two outposts in London, perhaps it’s no surprise that even the foyer, though paneled in varnished plywood and sparingly furnished, holds prized pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward’s New York Penthouse Is Listed for $9.95 Million
description: The celebrated couple bought the co-op overlooking Central Park in the early 1980s and used it as a pied-à-terre — and for big, splashy parties.
content: The longtime Manhattan home of Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, a sprawling penthouse at the exclusive 1120 Fifth Avenue co-op that they had used as a pied-à-terre and to entertain fellow movie stars and other prominent guests, is on the market for the first time in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Regimes of the Post-Post-Cold War World
description: The liberal world order, remixed.
content: My last newsletter before Thanksgiving was devoted to an argument about the potential resilience of both liberalism and democracy, even in a world where the post-Cold War liberal order becomes a distant memory. So naturally, this week, the president of South Korea, one of America’s most important democratic allies, decided to declare martial law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Fire at Baltimore Lumberyard Closes Highway and Schools
description: No one was injured or evacuated in the fire, which was made more challenging by the wind, the authorities said.
content: A fire broke out at a city-run lumberyard in Baltimore on Thursday evening and raged into the night, prompting the cancellation of Friday classes at two schools, and the closure of a section of a highway and a portion of the light rail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Blocks Release of Ethics Report on Gaetz as Republicans Close Ranks
description: In largely party-line votes, the House turned back two measures that would have forced the Ethics Committee to make public the results of its investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct and drug use.
content: The House on Thursday night blocked the release of a damaging Ethics Committee report about former Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, as Republicans voted to bury it, an expected move that makes it less likely the materials will ever be made public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: In Britain, Starmer Is Trying to Fight Populism From the Lonely Center
description: One of the last centrist leaders left on the global stage, Prime Minister Keir Starmer this week outlined his plan to deliver change for people in the U.K. Will it be enough?
content: Five months after his Labour Party won a thumping election victory, Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain finds himself a lonely figure: Like-minded centrist leaders in France and Germany are in retreat, while in the United States, Donald J. Trump and his populist message have vanquished the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Leader of Syria’s Resurgent Rebels Lays Out Strategy to Oust Assad
description: In an interview, Abu Mohammad al-Jolani, the Islamist rebel heading an offensive moving toward Damascus, said the operation was a long time coming.
content: Syrian rebels have swept through major cities and captured territory across four provinces in a dramatic new offensive, and the Islamist leader heading the charge says their aim is nothing short of ousting President Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Their Fertilizer Poisons Farmland. Now, They Want Protection From Lawsuits.
description: A company controlled by Goldman Sachs is helping to lead a lobbying effort by makers of fertilizer linked to “forever chemicals.”
content: For decades, a little-known company now owned by a Goldman Sachs fund has been making millions of dollars from the unlikely dregs of American life: sewage sludge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight, Amy Graff and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Californians Know About Earthquakes, but Tsunamis Are a Different Story
description: Northern California cities and residents seemed unsure on Thursday about the best response to an official tsunami warning that went out to five million Californians.
content: For generations, the possibility of another devastating earthquake has lingered in the minds of Californians, who are remarkably familiar with seismological terms and regularly prepare for the next “Big One.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 6, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about the challenges Speaker Mike Johnson will face with such a small Republican majority in the House misstated which parts of government Democrats currently control. They control the White House and the Senate, not the House and the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight, Kellen Browning and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Tsunami Warning in San Francisco ‘Felt Like a Science Fiction Movie’
description: Many Bay Area residents raced away from the ocean after a jolting cellphone alert warned, “You are in danger.” Others raced toward it.
content: With his surfboard tucked under his arm, Alex Felton was about to walk a couple of blocks to San Francisco’s Ocean Beach on Thursday morning when his cellphone blared. “TSUNAMI WARNING!” an alert screamed. “You are in danger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: The Best Children’s Books of 2024
description: Here are the year’s most notable picture, chapter and middle grade books, selected by our children’s books editor.
content: Twenty-six artfully designed, winningly goofy, faux-vintage record jackets gently spoof vinyl’s golden age, with animals standing in for iconic performers. One tune on each album gets the full treatment: lyrics by Bell plus an audio track composed and produced by her real-life musician pals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: As Jan. 6 Criminal Cases Against Trump Fizzle, Civil Cases Plod Ahead
description: Donald J. Trump has successfully defeated or impeded many legal challenges against him over the storming of the Capitol, but eight lawsuits on the matter remain in the courts.
content: There have been many efforts, over nearly four years, to hold Donald J. Trump accountable for the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but almost all of them have been stymied in the end by failure or delay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Notre-Dame Reopens: Here’s What to Know
description: Millions of visitors will flock to the Parisian cathedral after it reopens in December for the first time since a destructive fire in 2019.
content: Follow live updates on the Notre-Dame Cathedral reopening in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ghazvinian
title: Could Trump Make the Ultimate Deal With Iran?
description: Over the next four years, the toxic and seemingly unending psychodrama between the United States and Iran may very well see its final act.
content: In his first term as president, Donald Trump’s approach to Iran crossed almost every red line imaginable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Defends His Imperiled Pick for Defense Secretary, Pete Hegseth
description: The post amounted to a public dare to Republican senators, a number of whom have expressed private concerns about Mr. Hegseth, to vote against Mr. Trump’s wishes.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump was scheduled to give his first  gave a public show of support to his embattled choice for defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, on Friday morning, saying in a social media post that he will be “fantastic” in the job and that he has a “military state of mind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Elon and Vivek’s DOGE Goes to Congress
description: The tycoons in charge of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s amorphous government efficiency initiative made the rounds on Capitol Hill, bashing debt but revealing little about how they will tackle it.
content: As far as congressional meetings go, Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy’s huddle with Republicans was remarkably efficient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross, Liz Alderman and Patricia Cohen
title: As Trump Threatens Tariffs, Europe and South America Strengthen Ties
description: The European Union and four South American countries have reached an agreement to establish one of the largest trade zones in the world.
content: The European Union reached a major trade agreement on Friday with four South American countries, concluding a long-delayed negotiation that took on new urgency as President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened to impose tariffs on some of the world’s largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch the Stirring Climax of ‘The Piano Lesson’
description: The director Malcolm Washington narrates a sequence from the film featuring Danielle Deadwyler.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: In These Dark Times, Stand Up for Human Dignity
description: Organizations supporting vulnerable Haitian immigrants are under tremendous strain.
content: In the years ahead, many of us will be asking ourselves: Who is the most vulnerable to whatever comes next? It is, sadly, a rather long list. This has been a brutal year for people in many places across the globe. Sudan is in the grip of a merciless civil war. Bombs, disease and starvation stalk the people of Gaza. The people of Ukraine face another brutal winter in the maw of Russian aggression. These all deserve our attention, but I want to ask you, our readers, to think of someplace a little closer to home, a nation whose history and fate are so deeply intertwined with ours: Haiti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Hornyak and Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
title: In Japan, Designers Fit Big Ideas Into Tiny Homes
description: Some newer houses around the country are barely wider than a common family car.
content: In the labyrinthine back streets of Tokyo stands an odd geometric structure that looks nothing like the houses surrounding it. With its vertical wood siding, imposing oblong form and almost total lack of windows, it looks like an artwork, or a mini fortress. Appropriately enough, it’s called The Keep. And it’s designed as a home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Noah Weiland
title: Musk Cost-Cutting Effort Is Being Guided by Health Entrepreneur
description: The inclusion of Brad Smith in Trump’s efficiency panel suggests that the team is preparing to focus particularly on the nation’s health care system.
content: The government-efficiency panel started by Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy is being steered by a health care entrepreneur and former top health official in Mr. Trump’s first White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Stay or Go Chart
description: This is part of a chart that appeared in The New York Times this week. Do you know what it is about?
content: This is part of a chart that appeared in The New York Times this week. Do you know what news event it relates to? Why do you think The Times would have published it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The ‘Chilling’ Fatal Shooting of a C.E.O. Has Business Leaders on Edge
description: After Brian Thompson of UnitedHealthcare was killed in Manhattan, the phones at corporate security firms were “ringing off the hook.”
content: A Fortune 500 pharmaceutical company raised its drug prices, and then board members and executives received phone calls threatening violence. A health care company’s board meeting was disrupted after board members were targeted in “swatting” attacks that wrongly sent law enforcement officers to their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Opposition Grows to South Korea’s President as He Faces Impeachment
description: The leader of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party has backed impeachment, on which the National Assembly is set to vote on Saturday.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea grew increasingly isolated on Friday, after the head of his ruling party came out in support of impeaching the president, and the country’s military said it would not follow any orders to reimpose martial law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: A One-of-a-Kind Card Fuels a Treasure Hunt for the Ages
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates offered 30 years of season tickets in exchange for a Paul Skenes rookie card, and collectors say it could sell for $1 million. First, someone has to find it.
content: The hunt for rare sports trading cards can feel like a search for buried treasure. There are “chases” and “bounties” and card values that rise and fall like waves. So it makes perfect sense that, at the heart of one of the pastime’s most-hyped pursuits, is a lanky, towering and mustachioed (Pittsburgh) Pirate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Is the Urban Shift Toward Trump Really About Democratic Cities in Disarray?
description: Big cities have faced serious problems lately. But there’s little evidence those problems are what drove voters to the right in November.
content: The presidential election has raised an uncomfortable possibility for big American cities, most of them run by Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: 3 Quick and Easy Recipes for the Best-Ever Holiday Spread
description: Melissa Clark’s three filling, colorful and festive snacks are perfect for especially effortless entertaining.
content: Expectations for holiday entertaining run high. Whether it’s a giddily glittery cocktail bash or a more serenely elegant sit-down dinner, hosting any kind of gathering this time of the year can be extremely stressful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: How Childhood Tragedy Shaped the Doctor Trump Picked for Surgeon General
description: At the age of 13, Dr. Janette Nesheiwat said she accidentally knocked over a box in a darkened room. A handgun went off, leaving her father dead.
content: Needing a pair of scissors, a 13-year-old girl went into the bedroom where her father was sleeping and reached for a fishing tackle box on a shelf above the bed. But in the darkened room, she accidentally knocked it over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What Is Happening in Syria
description: We explain the latest updates in the country’s civil war.
content: The Syrian Civil War is a long-running tragedy. Since 2011, more than 500,000 Syrians have died, including more than 200,000 civilians, according to human rights experts. Millions more Syrians have fled their homes. The flood of refugees into Europe has been large enough to help destabilize politics in France, Germany, Italy and elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Diane Wong
title: Is Intel Cooked? + What’s Your P(Dyson Sphere)? + Hard Fork Gift Guide
description: The sudden departure of Intel’s C.E.O. reignites concerns about U.S. dependence on foreign manufacturing.
content: This week, Pat Gelsinger stepped down as chief executive of Intel. We talk with The New York Times’s Don Clark about why Gelsinger was ousted, what it means for the chip industry and how his departure could affect national security. Then, Kevin and Casey report back from an artificial intelligence conference, where experts debated how long it would take to build a structure around the sun to capture the star’s energy — also known as a Dyson sphere. And finally, gift guides have taken over the internet. We dig into why, and offer up suggestions for gear dads, home cooks and even tech billionaires in our first ever Hard Fork gift guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: No One Should Go Hungry in America
description: While lawmakers try to find long-term solutions to food insecurity, Feeding America is filling the void for tens of millions of Americans every day.
content: It is an astonishingly large number: 5.3 billion. That’s how many meals were distributed by the nation’s largest domestic hunger relief organization, Feeding America, in 2023 alone. In a country of more than 330 million people, it is evidence of how widespread and persistent food insecurity remains in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Trump’s Treasury Pick Isn’t Alarming, but He Is Unusual
description: Some of Scott Bessent’s economic views are outside the mainstream. But at least he’s qualified.
content: Scott Bessent, Donald Trump’s pick for Treasury secretary, has some pretty unorthodox views. Unorthodoxy can be a good thing at times, and it’s conceivable that Bessent will end up a big success at Treasury. But deviation from the norm is not necessarily what you look for in a Treasury secretary, who is responsible for formulating the nation’s economic, financial and tax policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: $570,000 Homes in Iceland
description: A contemporary home near a volcanic crater lake, and a pair of two-bedroom apartments in a harbor district of Reykjavík.
content: This three-bedroom, two-bath, contemporary-style house with a sauna is newly constructed in the municipality of Grímsnes, about an hour east of downtown Reykjavík, Iceland’s capital and largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Anusha Bayya
title: Most Serious Charge Dismissed in Subway Trial; Lesser Charge Remains
description: Jurors in the Daniel Penny trial in Manhattan deadlocked on Friday. Next week they will begin deliberating a lesser charge against him in the death last year of Jordan Neely.
content: The Manhattan judge overseeing the case of a man accused in the choking death of a  mentally ill subway passenger last year dismissed the most serious charge against him on Friday afternoon, leaving jurors to consider a lesser charge when they return to court next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Atrocities Made a South Korean City Infamous. A Novelist Made It Immortal.
description: The last time South Korea imposed martial law, Gwangju endured a deadly crackdown. Han Kang, the Nobel Prize-winning author, told its story in “Human Acts.”
content: Follow the latest news on South Korea and President Yoon Suk Yeol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Job Growth Rebounds With a Gain of 227,000 in November
description: Hiring bounced back after disruptions from storms and a major strike.
content: Job creation bounced back in November after disruptions from storms and a major strike, reinforcing a picture of modest employment expansion over the past several months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Trump Names Top Silicon Valley Conservative to Oversee Crypto and A.I.
description: David Sacks, a venture capitalist who hosts a hit podcast, has generally called for a looser hand in regulating both emerging technologies.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has named one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent conservative investors, donors and media personalities to help oversee American tech policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Trump Claims a ‘Historic’ Mandate. Polls Show Americans Have Mixed Feelings.
description: The public may have more nuanced views on issues like tariffs and mass deportations than it might seem at first blush.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies have declared that his incoming administration has an “unprecedented” and “historic” mandate. While he won the popular vote by only a small margin, it’s true that voters shifted in his favor across the country and sent him back to the White House. But does that equate to a full-throated endorsement of his policy proposals?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: A day after a health care executive was assassinated outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan, a frantic manhunt for the gunman continued. The authorities released two images that they said showed the face of the suspect, and a senior law enforcement official said he used a fake New Jersey identification to book a room at a hostel the night before the killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Is Your Choice for Word of the Year?
description: The Oxford English Dictionary picked “brain rot” as its 2024 Word of the Year. Do you agree?
content: Every year the Oxford English Dictionary selects a Word of the Year that is meant to reflect “the moods and conversations” that have shaped the previous year. For 2024, the publisher chose “brain rot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: World’s Oldest Known Wild Bird Lays an Egg at 74
description: Wisdom, a Laysan albatross, has outlived at least three mates and the researcher who outfitted her with a tracking band in 1956.
content: The world’s oldest known wild bird, a 74-year-old Laysan albatross named Wisdom, is expected to welcome another baby chick in the coming months, astonishing scientists who have been tracking her since the Eisenhower administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Thielman
title: The Best Graphic Novels of 2024
description: A sketchbook collection, a Joycean comedy and a brutal self-examination gave us a lot to look at.
content: The year 2024 was an especially good year for comics readers who had been waiting a long time. Olivier Schrauwen brought his magisterial “Sunday” to a close after five years. After 15, Chris Ware published the third volume in his trilogy of “Datebook” comics adapted from his sketchbooks. And Charles Burns finally completed and published in English the project he’d been serializing in French — “Dédales” to our European friends, “Final Cut” to us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Cryptocurrency You May Not Even Know You Own
description: Many funds hold stakes in MicroStrategy, which behaves like Bitcoin’s wilder cousin. This may not be what you want in your retirement portfolio, our columnist says.
content: Bitcoin has had a phenomenal year. But its rich returns are paltry compared with those of MicroStrategy, a company dedicated to a risky business: buying Bitcoin with money provided by you and other shareholders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams Doesn’t Rule Out Becoming a Republican Again
description: The Democratic mayor of New York City has embraced President-elect Donald J. Trump lately. He was a registered Republican in the 1990s.
content: With his political future in doubt, Eric Adams, the Democratic mayor of New York City, has opened the door to returning to the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Beyond the Blockbusters, 7 Key Songs From 1984
description: The Pointer Sisters, Minutemen and more sounds from a landmark year in pop music.
content: If you’re halfway decent at math, you know that it is currently the 40-year anniversary of 1984 — which is not only the name of a George Orwell novel and a Van Halen album, but a particularly pivotal moment in popular music. This week, we’re running a few articles that look back at the music of 1984, beginning with a sharp, well-reported piece by Ben Sisario about the way a number of ’70s rockers (ZZ Top, Don Henley and Yes among them) rebooted their sounds and images for the brave new world of the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Famous Christmas Poem Could Sell for $500,000
description: “A Visit From St. Nicholas” is the beginning of modern Christmas, a manuscript specialist at Christie’s said.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a copy of “A Visit From St. Nicholas” that only recently turned up. We’ll also get details on a lawsuit by the father of Jordan Neely, the 30-year-old homeless man who died in a chokehold on the subway last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Shelf-Stable Parmesan
description: Can an Italian American use “shaky cheese” if he’s cooking for a toddler?
content: Dean writes: My sisters give my wife and me grief for using “shaky cheese.” This is considered heresy in my Italian American family. But we don’t eat enough pasta to justify buying the expensive stuff. And with a 2-year-old son, we don’t have the time to labor over every meal the way my sisters do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pragati K.B., Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
title: As India-Bangladesh Tensions Rise, So Do Fears of Tit-for-Tat Violence
description: A diplomatic dispute over claims of persecution of Bangladeshi Hindus threatens to upend Bangladesh’s interim government.
content: Relations between India and neighboring Bangladesh reached a perilous new low this week as Indian politicians and Hindu extremists intensified accusations that minority Hindus in Bangladesh are being persecuted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rebels Advance in Syria as Iran Steps Back
description: Also, judges rejected TikTok’s effort to avoid a U.S. ban. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Syrian rebel groups fighting to depose President Bashar al-Assad pushed farther south today toward the major city of Homs. The government’s chief patron, Iran, moved to evacuate military commanders and other personnel after more than a decade of staunch support.

title: Rosé Sets Herself Free, and 8 More New Songs

content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: The Year in Pop: Hits Without Stars, Stars Without Hits

content: This past spring, Tommy Richman got famous off a TikTok.

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump’s F.B.I. Pick Has an Enemies List. Biden Should Pardon Everyone on It.
description: The president has a chance to save innocent people from MAGA persecution.
content: There are few good things to be said about Donald Trump’s plan to fire the F.B.I. director, Chris Wray, and install in his place Kash Patel, a thuggish lackey who has spent years fantasizing about taking revenge on Trump’s enemies. But there is one: Patel has helpfully provided us with a list of people President Biden should pardon before he leaves office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Tim Walz Says He Was ‘a Little Surprised’ Trump Won
description: In his first interviews since the election, Kamala Harris’s running mate told Minnesota television stations that he had thought the country would embrace the Democratic ticket’s positive message.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said this week that he was “a little surprised” that he and Vice President Kamala Harris lost the presidential election to Donald J. Trump because he had believed the country was ready for the Democratic ticket’s “positive message.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: He Mocked the Rich on TikTok for Fun. Now He Can Get $30,000 Per Post.
description: Aris Yeager’s “European Kid” videos have been an unexpected hit. Wealthy people and luxury brands have noticed.
content: A rich kid stands in the doorway of a marble-lined bathroom, a cellphone pressed to his ear. His face is strained. He’s yelling and waving his free arm. He swears in French, very clearly having a tantrum, with his father on the line, over money for a trip to Miami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Albert Sun
title: How Much Did Trump, Biden and Harris Raise? A Stunning $4.7 Billion.
description: That figure, which includes totals from the three presidential contenders’ main allied groups, emerged in the final federal filings of a staggeringly expensive campaign.
content: Donors spent an astonishing $4.7 billion on the presidential contenders in this year’s general election, piling that amount into the campaign coffers of Donald J. Trump, Kamala Harris, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and their main allied groups over the course of the contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: In Syria, a Rebel Offensive Shatters a Fragile Sense of Normalcy
description: Militants stormed out of their stronghold in Idlib Province last week, seizing parts of the nation’s largest city. A Times reporter puts the surprise attack in context.
content: The Arab Spring reached Syria in 2011, when a popular uprising met with a bloody response from President Bashar al-Assad and his government. Soon, Syria was entangled in civil war, with a patchwork of territories controlled variously by rebel groups, the Islamic State, Kurdish militias and government forces supported by foreign militaries. The conflict never really ended, but by mid-2020, the front lines had stopped moving, and Mr. al-Assad’s government had stood firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Trump Names 2 Officials to Help Carry Out Immigration Crackdown
description: The president-elect picked Rodney S. Scott, an outspoken Border Patrol chief from his first term, to run Customs and Border Protection. And he chose Caleb Vitello to head Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
content: President-elect Trump on Thursday tapped a pair of longtime officials for key roles in his planned immigration crackdown, including an outspoken Border Patrol chief from his first term whom the Biden administration ousted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Maitake au Poivre, Peruvian Roast Chicken, Pork Noodle Soup
description: Now’s the time for dinners that are simple and delicious and just for you.
content: Good morning. There was a Cooper’s hawk sitting on top of a road sign off the Long Island Expressway the other afternoon, in the wake of Thanksgiving. My daughter spotted it and was able to point it out to me because the traffic was crawling and thick. The bird looked under the weather, as I was at the time, and was staring vacantly out toward the Pine Barrens, as I had been staring vacantly at the sea of red brake lights before me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Everybody Loves FRED: How America Fell for a Data Tool
description: From Facebook political debates to college classrooms, the St. Louis Fed’s data tool has gained a major following.
content: Fans post about him on social media. Swag bearing his name sells out on the regular. College professors dedicate class sessions and textbook sections to him. Foreign government officials have been known to express jealousy over his skills, and one prominent economist refers to him as a “national treasure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Owner of Los Angeles Times Plans ‘Bias Meter’ Next to Coverage
description: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong said that he planned to introduce the tool, which he said would appear next to the paper’s news articles and opinion pieces, in January.
content: Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, the billionaire owner of The Los Angeles Times, said on Thursday that he planned to introduce a “bias meter” next to the paper’s news and opinion coverage as part of his campaign to overhaul the publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikki Mark
title: My Son Is Gone. Our Conversation Goes On.
description: Three days before my child unexpectedly died, he primed me to keep living.
content: Every night before I go to sleep, I write in a journal to my 12-year-old son, Tommy, and continue a conversation we started on April 13, 2018, just three days before he unexpectedly passed away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.

source.name: The New York Times

title: How a Book From 1981 Anticipated This Political Moment
description: Two columnists sit down to discuss two books that crystallize this period in America.
content: In this conversation, the New York Times Opinion columnists Carlos Lozada, a former book critic, and Pamela Paul, previously the editor of The Times’s Book Review, each share one book that, in their opinion, can help us understand this point in history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Milk to Be Tested for Bird Flu Virus
description: New federal rules call for testing unpasteurized milk from dairy processors and for farm owners to provide details that would help officials identify and track cases more easily.
content: The U.S. Department of Agriculture will begin testing the nation’s milk supply for the bird flu virus known as H5N1, nearly a year after the virus began circulating through dairy cattle, the department announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Was Brian Thompson’s Killer a Hit Man? Unlikely, Experts Say.
description: The murder of Brian Thompson did not appear to have been committed by a coldly calculating professional, according to people who study criminal behavior.
content: For the general public, the shooting in Manhattan of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare on Wednesday seemed like something off Netflix: a coldblooded morning murder outside a hotel, a hooded man shooting a corporate bigwig from behind, the victim turning to face the attacker before crumpling to the ground, mortally wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliot Higgins
title: Fact-Checkers Cannot Save Us
description: In our interconnected modern world, education is critical in the fight against disinformation.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: In Mexico, Heat Waves Are Even Killing Younger Adults
description: It’s not just the elderly. More than three-quarters of heat-related deaths in Mexico occurred among people younger than 35, researchers reported.
content: As climate change pushes global temperatures higher, attention has focused predominantly on the threat that heat poses to older adults, whose physiology makes them more susceptible to health complications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Head of Secret Service and Congressman Get Into Shouting Match at Hearing
description: The agency’s acting director took offense when a Texas representative questioned him about where he was standing in a photo commemorating the Sept. 11 attacks.
content: The acting director of the Secret Service and a Republican congressman from Texas got into a shouting match in a congressional hearing on Thursday over the acting director’s appearance in an official photo during a remembrance ceremony in New York on Sept. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Moves to Protect Arctic From Threats by Russia and China
description: Ottawa says its focus on the Arctic comes after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine “has shaken the foundations” of international cooperation in the northern region.
content: Citing growing interest by China and Russia in the Arctic as global warming makes the region more accessible, Canada on Friday said it would focus on building stronger alliances with other nations in the region, particularly the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Syria’s ‘Frozen Conflict’ Is Now Red Hot
description: When equilibriums are disrupted, chaos can ensue.
content: Geopolitics can often be best understood as an equilibrium — of expectations, of strength and of capabilities. When something upsets that balance, it can lead to chaos.

content: “Swept Away,” a darkly elegiac musical featuring the songs of the Avett Brothers, will end its Broadway run Dec. 15, less than a month after opening.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden Team Considers Blanket Pardons Before Trump’s Promised ‘Retribution’
description: White House officials believe President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selection of partisan warriors for top law enforcement jobs indicates that he will pursue revenge against his perceived enemies.
content: President Biden’s staff is debating whether he should issue blanket pardons for a swath of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s perceived enemies to protect them from the “retribution” he has threatened after he takes office, according to people familiar with the discussion.

title: She Revolutionized Medicine. Why Isn’t She a Household Name?
description: Lydia Reeder’s “The Cure for Women” tells the story of the remarkable Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi.
content: “I would be great,” wrote a 10-year-old Mary Putnam, circa 1852. “I would do deeds, so that after I had passed into that world, that region beyond the grave, I should be spoken of with affection.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Stewards of Czech Musical Heritage Return to Carnegie Hall
description: Over three nights, the Czech Philharmonic presented Dvorak’s concertos and more, including a rare performance of Janacek’s “Glagolitic Mass.”
content: You could be forgiven for thinking that there has been some kind of festival going on at Carnegie Hall.

description: Government forces appeared to be reinforcing crucial strongholds including the capital, Damascus, and the major city of Homs.
content: Syrian rebels pushed further south on Friday toward the major city of Homs, edging another step closer to the capital, Damascus, in their dramatic offensive, according to the rebels and a war monitoring group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: A Second Trump Term Is Set to Scramble Trade Alliances
description: Europe’s new pact with South America, its largest deal to date, could be a sign of how countries will diversify trade relationships as Donald Trump threatens tariffs.
content: Even before stepping back into the Oval Office, President-elect Donald J. Trump is prompting governments across the globe to rethink their trading relationships as they prepare for a four-year period in which business with the United States could become much more volatile.
source.name: The New York Times

content: The collection of rebel groups fighting to depose President Bashar al-Assad of Syria pushed further south on Friday toward a major city en route to the capital, as the government’s chief patron, Iran, moved to evacuate military commanders and other personnel from the country.

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: The Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of 2024
description: The year’s best speculative fiction includes a fantasy novel by Kelly Link, alien epics and promising starts to series.
content: Of the many great books I read this year, the following 10 have stayed with me, undergirded my thoughts as I go about my days and provoked excellent, chewy conversations about craft and pleasure, empire and resistance. While I’m a little haunted by the violence publishers seem to be doing to the very concept of a series — claiming sequels are stand-alones, while insufficiently supporting and labeling the parts of actual series — I hope you find something to enjoy among these fantastic works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Man Who Kidnapped Woman From Bloomberg’s Colorado Ranch Gets 22 Years in Prison
description: Joseph Beecher was intent on killing the media mogul and inquired about his family before taking a housekeeper hostage, officials said.
content: A man was sentenced on Thursday to 22 years in prison for breaking into a Colorado ranch belonging to Michael R. Bloomberg in 2022 and kidnapping a housekeeper in what prosecutors described as a failed plan to kill the media executive and former New York City mayor, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fresh Takes on Potato Salad
description: Plus: festive fashion, a new destination on the Brazilian coast and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: For Haitian Americans like the chef Gregory Gourdet, 49, potato salad bears little resemblance to the deli counter mainstay. Growing up in Queens, he instead ate salade russe, a traditional Haitian recipe in which potatoes are combined with peas, onions and beets, which turn the dish bubble gum pink. Today, Gourdet serves his own take on that dish as part of the summer menu at his restaurant Kann in Portland, Ore., smoking the beets and binding the ingredients with creamy rémoulade. It’s just one of a number of variations on Russian potato salad, known as Olivier — which was created in 19th-century Moscow and now shows up everywhere from Sweden to Korea — currently appearing on restaurant menus. At Eel Bar on New York’s Lower East Side, the chef-partner Aaron Crowder, 39, makes what he describes as a “New York version of the Spanish version of Russian potato salad,” informed by the ensaladilla rusa served at tapas bars that often includes green olives and roasted red peppers. He tops his with orange trout roe. Tyler Akin, 41, the chef and a partner at the Mediterranean restaurant Bastia in Philadelphia, makes potato confit in chicken fat and then mixes it with saffron-spiked aioli and shavings of Sardinian bottarga. Potato salad, he says, “just so clearly wants to be served warm and soft,” like the bacon-flecked, mayo-free German-style version that his family favors.
